message_1: A math student wants to form a committee of 3 people out of a group of 6. How many different committees can be formed? (Assuming that the order of the committee members does not matter.)
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where C(n, k) represents the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time, n! is the factorial of n, and k! is the factorial of k.

In this case, we have n = 6 (the total number of people) and k = 3 (the number of people in the committee).

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!(6-3)!)

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!3!)

C(6, 3) = (6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(3 × 2 × 1))

C(6, 3) = (720) / (6 × 6)

C(6, 3) = 720 / 36

C(6, 3) = 20

So, there are 20 different committees that can be formed.
